message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The history and physical examination indicate that the patient has a hordeolum, also known as a sty, which is a bacterial infection of the sebaceous gland at the base of an eyelash. Blepharitis is a chronic inflammation of the eyelid margin, Xanthelasma presents as yellowish plaques on the eyelid, and Chalazion is a non-infectious, painless, and slowly enlarging nodule in the eyelid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are consistent with Hordeolum, also known as a sty, which is an acute infection of the eyelid glands that form hair follicles. Blepharitis involves chronic inflammation of the eyelid margins, Xanthelasma involves yellowish deposits of cholesterol under the skin, and Chalazion involves a chronic inflammation of the eyelid glands that do not form hair follicles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a painful, warm, soft lump on the eyelid that drains purulent fluid is consistent with Hordeolum, also known as a stye. Blepharitis presents as redness and flaky, scaly skin around the eyelashes. Xanthelasma presents as yellow plaques on the eyelids. Chalazion presents as a hard lump on the eyelid, not typically associated with pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest a hordeolum, commonly known as a stye. It is a bacterial infection of the hair follicles in the eyelid. Blepharitis is an inflammation of the eyelid margin and Xanthelasma is a yellowish deposit of fat or cholesterol under the skin, typically around the eyes. A Chalazion is a painless bump on the eyelid caused by a blocked oil gland.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that it’s a hordeolum, which is an infection of the hair follicles of the eyelashes. It typically presents with a painful, warm, soft lump on the eyelid that may drain purulent fluid upon palpation. Blepharitis is an inflammation of the eyelids, Xanthelasma is a yellowish deposit of cholesterol underneath the skin, and Chalazion is a painless, slow-growing bump on the eyelid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of a painful, warm, soft lump on the eyelid draining purulent fluid suggest Hordeolum, also known as a stye. Blepharitis does not typically have a draining lump. Xanthelasma is a yellowish deposit under the skin, while Chalazion is a non-infectious, inflamed lump in the eyelid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the draining purulent fluid suggest a Hordeolum or a stye, which is an acute infection of the hair follicle of the eyelash. The other options are not likely diagnoses based on the symptoms presented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a Hordeolum, also known as a stye, which is a bacterial infection of the sebaceous gland in the eyelid. Blepharitis is a chronic inflammation of the eyelid margin and rarely involves purulent drainage. Xanthelasma is a yellowish deposit of fat underneath the skin, commonly found on the eyelids. Chalazion is a noninfectious, chronic inflammation of the meibomian gland in the eyelid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a painful, warm, soft lump on the eyelid with purulent drainage suggests a hordeolum, also known as a stye. Blepharitis is a chronic inflammation of the eyelid, Xanthelasma is a benign skin condition, and Chalazion is a painless, hard, and chronic lump on the eyelid.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of a painful, warm, soft lump on the eyelid that drains purulent fluid is consistent with the diagnosis of Hordeolum, which is a bacterial infection of the sebaceous glands in the eyelid. The other options have different presentations, such as Xanthelasma, which is a yellowish deposit of cholesterol in the skin around the eyes.
